## **Previously on 201: What is Linguistics**
<br>
.pull-left[
- Linguistics is the <u><span style="color:white"><b>scientific</b></span></u> study of language
<br><br>
- linguists use the scientific method to uncover the <u><span style="color:white"><b>combetence</b></span></u> or knowledge of language users
<br><br>
- while there are both prescriptive and descriptive rules relating to language, linguists are interested in uncovering the <u><span style="color:white"><b>describtive</b></span></u> rules of a language
<br><br>
- often times these rules are <u><span style="color:white"><b>tacit</b></span></u>, hence speakers are not aware that they are following them
<br><br>
- we can use the scientific method to uncover rules of languages we ourselves speak or languages we are unfamiliar with
]
.pull-right[
<br><br>
<img src="../pic/0129/image.png" width="100%">
]

## **Different Parts of Linguistic Competence**
<br>
.pull-left[<img src="../pic/0129/subfield.jpg" width="80%">]
.pull-right[
- Linguistics is the scientific study of human languages<br><br>
  - <u>**Morphology studies word structure**</u><br><br>
  - **Syntax** studies <span style="color:green"><b>sentence</b></span> structure<br><br>
  - **Semantics** studies <span style="color:green"><b>literal meaning</b></span> of words and sentences<br><br>
  - **Pragmatics** studies <span style="color:green"><b>contextual meaning</b></span> of words and sentences<br><br>
  - **Phonetics** studies speech <span style="color:green"><b>sounds</b></span><br><br>
  - **Phonology** studies <span style="color:green"><b>sound patterns</b></span>
]

## **Some Relations are Arbitrary**
<br>
.pull-left[
- as pointed out by **Ferdinand de Saussure** the relationship between sound/sign and meaning appears to be **arbitrary**<br><br>
- the fact that the sound [dɑg] has a meaning ‘a domesticated carnivorous mammal’ <u>does NOT appear to rely on</u> special properties of those sounds in that order<br><br><br>
- what is ‘a domesticated carnivorous mammal’ in other languages?
]
.pull-right[
<img src="../pic/0129/saussure.png" width="65%">
<br><br>
*Ferdinand Mongin de Saussure* (1857-1913)
]
 
---
## **Looking at Different Languages**
<br>
.pull-left[
- sound-meaning arbitrariness becomes clear when we look at **other languages**<br><br>
- the <span style="color:green"><b>same meaning</b></span> associated with <span style="color:blue"><b>different sounds</b></span><br><br>
  - inu (Japanese)
  - gae (Korean)
  - aso (Tagalog)
  - hundur (Icelandic)
  - Hund (German)...<br><br>
- or the <span style="color:blue"><b>same sound</b></span> associated with <span style="color:green"><b>different meaning</b></span> <br><br>
  - [q<sup>h</sup>urt] in **Kazakh**<br>
  ‘insect’ <br>
  ‘a type of food made from milk’
]
.pull-right[

## **Mental Dictionary (Lexicon)**
<br>
- part of language learning then is learning and memorizing these **meaning-sound pairs** and storing them in your **mental dictionary** (aka **lexicon**)<br><br>
- each item in the lexicon is a **lexical entry**<br><br>
- we know that part of each lexical entry is its *phonological representation* (written in IPA) and its *semantic representation*<br><br>
<table style="width:50%; border-collapse:collapse;">
  <tr>
    <td style="width:15%; text-align:center; border:1px solid black;">label</td>
    <td style="width:15%; text-align:center; border:1px solid black;"><span style="color:#CC0033">'dog'</span></td>
    <td style="width:15%; text-align:center; border:1px solid black;"><span style="color:#CC0033">'teach'</span></td>
  </tr>
  
  <tr>
    <td style="width:15%; text-align:center; border:1px solid black;"><b>phonological representation</b></td>
    <td style="width:15%; text-align:center; border:1px solid black;">/dɑg/</td>
    <td style="width:15%; text-align:center; border:1px solid black;">/tiːtʃ/</td>
  </tr>
  
  <tr>
    <td style="width:15%; text-align:center; border:1px solid black;"><b>semantic representation</b></td>
    <td style="width:15%; text-align:center; border:1px solid black;">{x: x is a dog}</td>
    <td style="width:15%; text-align:center; border:1px solid black;">{&lt;x, y&gt;: x teaches y}</td>
  </tr>
</table>

## **Compositionality**
<br>
.pull-left[
- **NOT** all pairs of sounds and meanings are arbitrary (actually most aren't)<br><br>
- the following string of phones (sounds) has a **predictable** meaning<br><br>
- and is almost certainly **NOT** stored as a single lexical entry<br><br>
  - [mɜːlɪns titʃər wɑkt kwɪkli]<br>
  'Merlin’s teacher walked quickly.'<br><br>
- the meaning of this string is predictable from the meanings of its parts<br><br>
- it is **COMPOSITIONAL**
]
.pull-right[
<br><br>
<img src="../pic/0129/compositional.jpg" width="90%">
<br><br>
<div style="text-align:center">
'*compositionality*'
</div>
]

## **Compositionality**
<br>
.pull-left[
  - [<span style="color:green"><b>mɜːlɪns</b></span> <span style="color:blue"><b>titʃər</b></span> <span style="color:orange"><b>wɑkt</b></span> <span style="color:#CC0033"><b>kwɪkli</b></span>]<br>
  '<span style="color:green"><b>Merlin’s</b></span> <span style="color:blue"><b>teacher</b></span> <span style="color:orange"><b>walked</b></span> <span style="color:#CC0033"><b>quickly</b></span>.'<br><br>

How is each word in the sentence **compositional**?<br><br>

- words like <span style="color:green"><b>Merlin’s</b></span> and <span style="color:blue"><b>teacher</b></span> **CAN** be broken down 
- and their meaning seems to contain the meaning of the pieces<br><br>
- while a word like **dog**, **CANNOT** be broken down into smaller meaningful units 
- it could be broken down into smaller sounds, but those sounds do not correspond to a meaning on their own
]

.pull-right[
<span style="color:green"><b>Merlin’s</b></span> and <span style="color:blue"><b>teacher</b></span>
  - morphologically complex words<br>
  
**dog** and **teach**
  - morphologically simple words<br><br>
<img src="../pic/0129/compositional.jpg" width="90%">
]

## **Zooming in on *-er***
<br>
.pull-left[
- what do these words all have **in common** in terms of their meaning? 
<br><br>
  - teach**er**
  - driv**er**
  - lectur**er**
  - read**er**
  - soften**er**
  - whiten**er**
  - blend**er**
  - moderniz**er**<br><br>
- -er seems to have a **shared and stable meaning**, something like '<i>one who does X action</i>', where X is a **verb**
]

## **Zooming in on *-er***
<br>
.pull-left[
<br><br>
- *-er* is used **productively**<br><br>
- it can be used to create novel words<br><br>
- the verb **yeet** is a fairly new verb<br><br>
- if you know the meaning of **yeet**<br><br>
- the term **yeeter** is easily understandable<br><br>
- even if you have never heard it before
]

## **Morphemes**
<br>
### teach, dog, fish and -er, un-, -able are all **morphemes**
<br><br>
.pull-left[
<br>
<img src="../pic/0129/suffix.jpg" width="100%">
]
.pull-right[
<br><br>
**morpheme**
- the minimal unit of phonology-meaning correspondence.
- in other words, a morpheme is a string of sounds whose meaning cannot be broken down into smaller meaningful units <br><br>
]

## **Smallest Linguistic Unit** with Meaning
<br>
.pull-left[
- we use **hyphens** (-) to indicate morpheme boundaries<br><br>
- morphemes are **NOT** the same as syllables:
  - *<span style="color:green">elephant</span>* has three syllables, but only <b>one</b> morpheme
  - *<span style="color:green">el</span>*, *<span style="color:green">e</span>*, *<span style="color:green">phant</span>* don’t mean anything – they’re syllables, but not morphemes<br><br>
- morphemes are made of **sounds**, NOT letters:
  - *<span style="color:green">silly</span>* and *<span style="color:green">silli</span>*- are two ways of spelling the same morpheme
  - same with *<span style="color:green">big</span>*, *<span style="color:green">bigg</span>*-er and *<span style="color:green">lie</span>*, *<span style="color:green">ly</span>*-ing
  - don’t worry about spelling differences
]
.pull-right[
.pull-left[
<br><br><br>
<span style="color:blue"><b><i>school-bus</i></b><br><br>
<span style="color:blue"><b><i>bee</i></b><br><br>
<span style="color:blue"><b><i>elephant</i></b><br><br>
<span style="color:blue"><b><i>open-er</i></b><br><br>
<span style="color:blue"><b><i>silli-est</i></b>
]
.pull-right[]
]

---
## **Smallest Linguistic Unit** with Meaning
<br>
.pull-left[
- note that it’s OK for a word to have **just one** morpheme
  - every word has at least one morpheme, some have more<br><br>
- words with one morpheme are called **monomorphemic** or **simplex words**
  - *bee*, *elephant*<br><br>
- words with two or more morphemes are **polymorphemic** or **complex words**
  - *school-bus*, *open-er*, *silli-est*<br><br>
- sometimes you’ll hear terms like **bimorphemic** or **trimorphemic**
  - what do you think they mean?
]
.pull-right[
.pull-left[
<br><br><br>
<span style="color:blue"><b><i>school-bus</i></b><br><br>
<span style="color:blue"><b><i>bee</i></b><br><br>
<span style="color:blue"><b><i>elephant</i></b><br><br>
<span style="color:blue"><b><i>open-er</i></b><br><br>
<span style="color:blue"><b><i>silli-est</i></b>
]
.pull-right[]
]

## **Finding morphemes in other languages**
### (Inuktitut, Eskaleut)

## **Lexical Category / Parts of Speech**
<br>
.pull-left[<img src="../pic/0129/pos.jpg" width="90%">]
.pull-right[
- **Noun (N.)**: to name things, people, places, concepts, etc.
  - *water*, *sister*, *sky*<br><br>
  - combine with plural morpheme -s; 
  - often ends with -ion/-ment/...; 
  - occur after a determiner, ...<br><br>
- <span style="color:green"><b>Verb (V.)</b></span>: to show an action or a state<br>
  - *play*, *think*, *hit*<br><br>
  - combine with past morpheme -d, has combined with -ize, ... 
  - follow an auxiliary (does), modal (might), or negation (not), ...
]
  
---
## **Lexical Category / Parts of Speech**
<br>
.pull-left[<img src="../pic/0129/pos.jpg" width="90%">]
.pull-right[
- <span style="color:blue"><b>Adjective (Adj.)</b></span>: to describe a noun, a pronoun or part of a sentence<br>
  - *tall*, *thin*, *smart*
  - comparative    e.g., bigger
  - superlative   e.g., biggest<br><br>
  - combine with un-, has combined with -able, ... 
  - occur between a determiner and a noun, ... <br><br>

- <span style="color:orange"><b>Adverb (Adv.)</b></span>:
  - *carefully*, *intentionally*, *happily*<br><br>
  - appear with -ly, ... 
  - can’t appear between a determiner and a noun, ...
]
  
---
## **Lexical Category / Parts of Speech**
<br>
How do we know that <span style="color:green"><b>wabe</b></span> is a **noun**, and that <span style="color:green"><b>slithy</b></span> is an **adjective**?
<br><br>
<div style="text-align:center">
Twas brillig, and the slithy toves <br><br>
Did gyre and gimble in the wabe; <br><br>
All mimsy were the borogoves, <br><br>
And the mome raths outgrabe. <br><br>
<div style="font-size:0.85em">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Lewis Carroll, <i>Jabberwocky</i> (1871)
</div>

<br>
From the examples given for each of the following suffixes, determine:<br><br>
  1. the lexical category (i.e. parts of speech) of the **root**
  2. the lexical category (i.e. parts of speech) of the word resulting from the addition of the **suffix**
<br><br><br><br>

.pull-left[
a. -ive: <u>*repressive*, *active*, *disruptive*, *explosive*</u><br><br>
b. -ion: <u>*invention*, *narration*, *expression*, *pollution*</u><br><br>
c. re-: <u>*reelect*, *resubmit*, *restart*, *recap*, *reactivate*</u>
]
.pull-right[
**-ive** takes <u><span style="color:white">verb</span></u>, yields <u><span style="color:white">noun</span></u><br><br>

]
